is “something from the beginning”? He said: What do you call it?

He asked: In the shramana conduct, what conduct is it? He said: the conduct of animals. What is the conduct of animals?
He said: Fur-clad and horned. What is the shramana conduct of fur-clad and horned? He said: Thing after thing
is not interrupted. What is the matter of “not interrupted”? He said: only then is it conduct. What is
a person who is fur-clad and horned? He said: not fearing karma. Why does it come to such a place?
He said: If one does not fear karma, what place could one not reach?

He asked: Entering sagehood from the ordinary, I will not ask. When entering the ordinary from the sage, how is it? He said: a
water-buffalo. What is the water-buffalo? He said: dim and dull, bleary-eyed. What does this mean?
He said: only thinking of water and grass, knowing nothing else. What side-matter does that make? He said:
Just when meeting grass, eat grass; when meeting water, drink water. The master also said: These words have
power. If you want to know their power: this person does not cling to shramana-side matters, nor does he enter the
reward-rank of the sages. That is precisely entering among the different kinds. This “different kind” is fur-clad and horned, called
shramana conduct. It is also called the place of the shramana’s travel provisions. It is also called “head three chi long,
neck two cun short.” If you want to know this meaning: when it comes to shramana conduct, one does not wish
to use measurements to distinguish intimacy and distance; one must not speak of Zhang San and Li Si. Moreover, “head three
chi long” means only that from small to great, today the work is completed; when it arrives at such a time,
it is called supreme phrases, wondrous phrases. “Neck two cun short” means not sitting in the shramana rank,
nor abiding in the sages’ reward rank. Therefore it is “neck two cun short.” At such a time one
must not speak of fitting or not fitting. Therefore it is said: do not bring measurements here
to think it over. Even so, this is still a matter on the “kind” side. You must know there are matters within the different
kind. Do you not see it said: Where wisdom does not reach, one must not speak of it. If you speak of it,
horns and a head arise. It is called thusness; that is already a change. One must proceed within the different kind.
It is called “emptying one position.” It is called “face-to-face, with inclusion.” Completely without any “this.” Indeed.
He asked: What is “kind”? He said: Fur-clad and horned. What is “different”? He said: How, how.
What is “conduct”? He said: If you want the head, then chop it off. Just so: what side-matter does the different kind
make? He said: In this matter there are two kinds of “different kind.” One is
the shramana different kind; the second is the “different kind in affairs.” The “different kind in affairs” is the civet-cat slave
and the white ox. The shramana different kind is: wherever one touches, one attains freedom; only then does one attain not
changing. It is not like that one. The former master asked me: Where are you going? I said: To the place of not changing.
He also said: This matter of not changing has two kinds. One is that each
and every person fully has their own original matter. The second is that those who know there is such a thing do not abandon any
sounds and forms, right and wrong; in all things and every thing they do not stick. It is called “in every place, not
changing.” “Gai” goes with the departing tone; the sounds differIt is also called fur-clad and horned; it is also called entering mud and entering water.
It is also called the fellow with travel provisions. He asked: What is entering mud and entering water? He said: not
changing. Does it turn around or not? He said: It does not turn around. How are this person’s household matters?
He said: The sages cannot measure it. Why can they not measure it? He said: Because he is not the same as
the sages. This is still a matter on the “kind” side—are there still matters above it or not? He said: There are. Thus,
what are the matters above? He said: If I tell you, I fear it will fall onto the “kind” side.

cb:div.head: Three LampsBefore and after, exactly three
cb:div.p:
The master said: What is called “before the lamp is lit” has two kinds. One: not yet knowing there is such a thing—like the milk
of the same kind of blood. Two: knowing there is such a thing—like obtaining the original thing before intention has sprouted. This is called “before the
lamp is lit.” One kind of knowing there is such a thing: coming and going in words, sounds and forms, right and wrong—also not belonging to
correct illuminating function, also not receiving prediction—like the milk of the same kind of blood; this is a matter on the side of leakage and loss.
This is called “after the lamp is lit.” Straight on, the affairs of the three times are exhausted; inner and outer feelings are forgotten; attaining no
interruption—only then is it called the correct lighting of the lamp; then it is said one receives prediction.
